questions.text: The cannabinoid receptors are absent in the ______
questions.solution:
Cannabinoid receptors are absent in the brainstem.

A specific receptor for the cannabinols, the cannabinoid receptor, is a member of the G-protein-linked family of receptors, which is linked to the inhibitory G protein (Gi).

Distribution of cannabinoid receptors in the brain:

Highest concentration:

  • Basal ganglia
  • The hippocampus
  • The cerebellum

Lower concentration: The cerebral cortex

Absent: The brainstem - This explains the minimal effects of cannabis on respiratory and cardiac function.

questions.text: A man diagnosed with schizophrenia was on chlorpromazine and olanzapine for the past 6 months. However, he is still symptomatic. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is the drug of choice in treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizophrenia with persistent suicidality.

Treatment-resistant schizophrenia is the lack of response to two different antipsychotics given at adequate dosages for an adequate duration of 4-6 weeks.

If patients demonstrate even a mild amount of improvement during this period, it may be reasonable to wait before changing a medication, since patients may improve at a steady rate for 3 to 6 months.

Here, the patient’s medication history indicates a poor response to 2 antipsychotic trials, hence clozapine is indicated.

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation

Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia 

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

Clozapine treatment guidelines:

Indications:  Treatment resistant schizophrenia, schizophrenia associated with suicidality.

  • Agranulocytosis

questions.text: It is said that practise makes one perfect because an act that is repeatedly performed leads to:

choices.text: Activation of the hippocampal memory circuits
Activation of the medial temporal lobe
A repeated act gets encoded within the frontal cortex

questions.solution:
The "corticalization of motor commands" is the neuroanatomical basis for the adage "practice makes perfect."

Performing an unskilled act requires widespread activation of the cortex and when start to memorise an act, it initially requires activation of the medial temporal lobe.

However, as we continue practising, larger segments of an act become encoded within discrete areas of the premotor and parietal cortices, particularly the left parietal cortex.

Now, when the practised act is performed, the medial temporal lobe will be bypassed as it is no longer needed because the act has already been encoded in the discrete areas of the cortex. 

As a result, with practise, only a limited activation of those areas of the cortex encoded with the act is necessary.

This is called corticalisation of motor commands and it is the reason why we perform a practised act better and faster. Thus, it is said that practise makes perfect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a core feature of Dementia with Lewy Body?
questions.solution:
Autonomic dysfunction is not a core feature of Dementia with Lewy Body(DLB).

Core features of DLB:

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations, which are typically well-formed and detailed.
  • Spontaneous motor features of parkinsonism.
    • The most common - rigidity and bradykinesia, followed by hypophonic speech, masked facies, stooped posture, and a slow and shuffling gait.
    • Resting tremors may occur, but are less common.
  • Other supporting clinical features suggestive of DLB include REM sleep behavior disorder and severe neuroleptic sensitivity.
  DLB Parkinsonism
Resting tremor + +++
Temporal Relationship Dementia -> Parkinsonism Parkinsonism -> Dementia

Lewy bodies are composed predominantly of fibrillar deposits of α-synuclein, and can also include neurofilament proteins and ubiquitin.

Classic Lewy bodies: Inclusions with a hyaline core and pale halo are typically seen in the brain stem nuclei, substantia nigra, and locus coeruleus.

Cortical Lewy bodies: Less-well-defined spherical inclusions.

questions.text: Under the DSM-5 classification, what does the axis V represent?
questions.solution:
There is no Axis V in the DSM 5 classification. Thus, none of the above is the answer.

The multi-axial system of classification was present in the DSM IV classification. The multiaxial evaluation under DSM –IV (now obsolete) were:

  • Axis I- clinical psychiatric diagnosis
  • Axis II- personality disorder and mental retardation
  • Axis III – physical disorder and general medical conditions
  • Axis IV- psychosocial and environmental problems
  • Axis V- global assessment and functioning 

DSM-5 has discarded the multiaxial system of diagnosis and made the following changes:

  • Listed all the disorders in Section II.
  • Replaced Axis IV with significant psychosocial and contextual features.
  • Dropped Axis V(Global Assessment of Functioning) and added the WHO's Disability Assessment Schedule to Section III.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with symptoms of low mood, fatigue, and inability to experience pleasure in any activities. He also complains of insomnia and lack of concentration. These symptoms are present during the months of winter and completely remit during spring. On further questioning, you find that he is a laborer who is always left unemployed during the winter months. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern

questions.solution:
Major depressive disorder is the most likely diagnosis in this case. 

DSM-V criteria for diagnosis of depression:

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Anhedonia- diminished interest in day-to-day activities
  3. Significant weight loss or weight gain and/or change in appetite.
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive, inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death and suicide

At least five out of nine symptoms must be present over a two-week period and one symptom must be depressed mood or anhedonia. 

Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern (option B) is not the diagnosis as there is the presence of a psychosocial stressor (e.g., seasonal unemployment or school schedule). It is explicitly mentioned in the question that the patient always remains unemployed during the winter months which acts as the objective psychological stressor in this case.

Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern refers to the onset and remission of major depressive episodes at specific times of the year. In most cases, the episodes begin in the fall or winter and remit in spring. Major depressive episodes that occur in a seasonal pattern are often characterized by prominent energy, hypersomnia, overeating, weight gain, and a craving for carbohydrates. This pattern of onset and remission of episodes must have occurred during at least a 2-year period, without any nonseasonal episodes during this period. 

Dysthymia (option C) is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. Dysthymia will also never present with an episode of mania/hypomania.

Cyclothymia (option D) is a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy lasting for at least 4 consecutive days. The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

questions.text: Which of the following patients with personality disorders is most likely to benefit from dialectical behavior therapy?

choices.text: A 18-year-old with traits of criminality, impulsivity, hostility, manipulation, and disregard for others
A 20-year-old with labile emotions, dramatic speech, who is sexually provocative with attention seeking behaviours
A 22-year-old with traits of unstable mood, impulsivity, suicidality, fear of abandonment, and unstable self-image
A 24-year-old who is preoccupied with order, perfectionism, and is excessively devoted to work

questions.solution:
Dialectical behavior therapy is a type of psychotherapy used commonly in the management of borderline personality disorder.

A 22-year-old with traits of unstable mood, impulsivity, suicidality, fear of abandonment, and unstable self-image fits the description of borderline personality disorder as per DSM-5 criteria.

In DBT, the goal is to improve interpersonal skills and decrease self-destructive behavior using techniques involving advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation, among others.

Option A: This describes a patient with antisocial personality disorder.

Option B: This describes a patient with histrionic personality disorder.

Option D: This describes a patient with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.

questions.text: A patient presents with mental confusion, visual and auditory hallucinations, perceived changes of body shape, swelling of the tongue, and a fear of impending death after he was treated for primary chancre of syphilis with an intramuscular injection. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has Hoigne Syndrome as he developed acute psychotic symptoms after intramuscular administration of penicillin G for the treatment of syphilis.

Hoigne syndrome:

  • Acute psychotic symptoms due to a pseudoanaphylactic or pseudoallergic reaction that occurs after intramuscular administration of penicillin G procaine or benzathine.
  • These are usually embolic toxic reactions possibly due to vascular occlusion by large crystals of the penicillin salts. It is not due to Penicillin allergy. 
  • The patient presents with mental confusion, visual and auditory hallucinations, perceived changes of body shape, swelling of the tongue and a fear of impending death.

A Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a reaction to endotoxin-like products released by the death of harmful micro-organisms within the body following antibiotic treatment.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with academic and behavioral problems at school over the past year was diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. On neuroimaging, which of the following is most likely to be seen?

choices.text: Pathologic alterations in the frontal lobe
Structural anomalies in the frontal lobe
Lesion in the Ascending Reticular Activating System

questions.solution:
Functional neuroimaging studies show frontal lobe hypometabolism in patients with ADHD.

The frontal lobe maintains attention, arousal, or the establishment and maintenance of an awake state. This appears to require at least three brain regions:

  • Ascending reticular activating system (ARAS)
  • Intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus
  • Frontal lobes

In ADHD, although no specific pathological lesions are found in the ARAS, thalamic or cortical level, functional neuroimaging indicates frontal lobe hypometabolism.

  • Neuromuscular hyperActivity (clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure), 
  • Autonomic stimulation (hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhoea), and

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contribution by Sigmund Freud?
questions.solution:
Sigmund Freud is credited with all the above-mentioned achievements except psychosocial theory (proposed by Erik Erikson).

Contributions of Sigmund Freud to the field of psychiatry:

  • Free association
  • Interpretation of dreams
  • Psychoanalysis
  • Psycho-sexual development 
  • Psychodynamic theory 
  • Topographic theory of the mind - unconscious, preconscious, conscious
  • Structural theory of mind - id, ego, super-ego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry

Option A: Concept of free association is a technique in psychoanalysis where the patient is asked to freely share thoughts, random words, and anything else that comes to mind.

Option B: Cocaine was introduced in psychiatry as a remedy for morphine and alcohol abuse.

Option C: Psychodynamic theory of development explains personality in terms of the interaction between the conscious and unconscious forces of id, ego, and super-ego.

questions.text: An elderly patient was referred from the medicine OPD with paranoid ideation and suspiciousness. He has also been having inappropriate outbursts of rage for the past 1 year and memory issues for the past 3 months. He is unable to dress by himself or manage his daily activities, such as cooking or cleaning. Imaging was done and the following findings were seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the scan indicating atrophy of frontal and parietal lobes are suggestive of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), one of which is Pick's disease.

Pick's disease presents with early personality changes (frontal lobe involvement) and loss of social restraints initially, followed by memory loss. By contrast, Alzheimer's patients present with memory loss first and then develop personality changes. 

Other features include loss of insight, easy distractibility, reduced concern or empathy for others, emotional lability or withdrawal, impulsiveness, poor self-care, and perseveration.

There is a second type of presentation of FTD, which is characterized by an early and progressive change in language, with problems of expression of language or severe naming difficulty, and problems with word meaning.

The classic imaging findings seen in FTD are preferential atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes with occipitoparietal sparing.

Histopathology:

  • Pick cells (swollen neurons) in affected areas of the brain
  • Pick bodies (intraneuronal argentophilic inclusions)

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
All of the following are related to schizophrenia except PANDAS.

SOAR (Schizophrenia Online Access to Resources) is a multifamily intervention for people with schizophrenia and their support persons.

HORYZONS system is an online platform developed for long-term recovery of people experiencing a first episode of psychosis. 

FOCUS is the first smartphone intervention specifically designed for people with schizophrenia. 

PANDAS is an acronym for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections. A child may be diagnosed with PANDAS when obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), tic disorder, or both suddenly appear following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A 65-year-old retired officer has been confined to his house since the COVID-19 pandemic started in March 2020. He does not have any visitors and has lost touch with his family as well. He has been having persistent feelings of low mood and sees no purpose in his life. He sometimes has thoughts about killing himself. Which of the following sleep changes occur in this disorder?

choices.text: An increase in total sleep time

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of depression (major depressive disorder). It is associated with a premature loss of deep (slow-wave) sleep.

Sleep changes in depression:

  • A premature loss of deep (slow-wave) sleep
  • An increase in nocturnal arousal manifested as:
    • An increase in nocturnal awakenings
    • A reduction in total sleep time
    • Increased phasic rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
    • Increased core body temperature

The combination of increased REM drive and decreased slow-wave sleep results in a significant reduction in the first period of non-REM (NREM) sleep, a phenomenon referred to as reduced REM latency.

questions.text: DSM–5 criteria for major neurocognitive disorder include all except ______

choices.text: Significant cognitive decline from a previous level of functioning in one or more cognitive domains
The deficits do not occur exclusively during the course of delirium
The deficits cannot be explained by another mental disorder
The cognitive deficits do not interfere in independence in daily activities

questions.solution:
The cognitive deficits interfere in independence in daily activities in a major neurocognitive disorder.

DSM-5 Criteria for Major Neurocognitive Disorder

A. Significant cognitive decline from a previous level of functioning in one or more cognitive domains(attention, executive function, language, social cognition, learning, and memory) as evidenced by:

  • Concern from the individual, the clinician or another knowledgeable informant.
  • Significant impairment in cognitive performance on neuropsychological testing.

B. Cognitive deficits interfere in independence in daily activities.

C. The deficits do not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

D. The deficits cannot be explained by another mental disorder.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a history of sore throat two weeks ago presents with sudden onset of motor tics and emotional lability. A diagnosis of PANDAS was made. Which of the following may also be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infection (PANDAS) is associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder in children.

PANDAS results from the immune response of the body to Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus infection. The antibodies directed against the bacteria cross-react with self-tissues due to molecular mimicry. The pathophysiology behind PANDAS is postulated to be the same as that of Sydenham chorea which occurs during acute rheumatic fever.

The diagnosis of PANDAS is based on:

  • Abrupt onset and episodic course of symptoms
  • Pediatric onset (age between 3 years and adolescent)
  • Temporal relation between Group A  β-hemolytic Streptococcus infection and the symptoms
  • Presence of OCD and/or a tic disorder (such as a motor or a vocal tic)

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Delusion is a disorder of content of thought.

Neologism, derailment, and tangentiality are formal thought disorders.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A patient is mute and immobile but conscious. He is unresponsive to the environment. How would you describe his state?
questions.solution:
A patient is said to be in a stupor when he is conscious but mute, immobile, and unresponsive to the environment.

  Stupor Sopor Coma
Consciousness Conscious, but mute and immobile Drowsy, abnormally deep sleep, difficult to arouse Unconscious, cannot be awakened
Response to the environment No/Decreased Responds to harsh sound, bright light No 
Response to painful stimulus Yes Yes No
 

Option A: Akinetic mutism: The person is mute and immobile but responsive to the environment.

Option D: Twilight state: A state of disturbed consciousness with hallucinations, during which actions may be performed unconsciously.

Note: The oneiroid state is a dream-like state in which patients may be deeply confused and not fully oriented to time and place. The term oneiroid schizophrenia has been used for patients who are engaged in their hallucinatory experiences to the point of exclusion of involvement in the real world.

questions.text: Select the correct statement:

choices.text: Damage to the left hemisphere leads to loss of insight
Damage to the right hemisphere can trigger depression
Patients with left temporal lobe epilepsy maybe philosophical and humorless
Patients with left temporal lobe epilepsy may display excessive emotions

questions.solution:
Patients with left Temporal Lobe Epilepsy may generate references to personal destiny and philosophical themes and display a humorless approach to life.

The left hemisphere is responsible for analysis. The right hemisphere is responsible for affect, humor, socialization, and body image. Within the hemispheres, the temporal and frontal lobes play a prominent role in emotion.

Dysfunctions of Right Hemisphere:

  • Lesion in the right hemisphere:
    • Because the left hemisphere is intact, which is analytical and not emotional, and the damaged right hemisphere is unable to emote, the patient will show an indifference to the illness and therefore portray a lack of insight, which is called anosognosia.
    • There will be a loss of right hemispheric functions.
    • Eg: If a patient is unable to move his left hand, but denies to have any problem and is humorless, it is a case of right hemisphere injury.
  • Overactivation of the right hemisphere: As  seen in right Temporal Lobe Epilepsy, will lead to an excessive emotionality.

Dysfunction of Left Hemisphere:

  • Lesion in the left hemisphere:
    • The intact right hemisphere will struggle with the loss as it is highly emotional and left unchecked by the damaged left hemisphere, which will lead to a catastrophic depression.
    • There will be a loss of left hemispheric functions (intellectual disorder, aphasia).
  • Overactivation  of the left hemisphere: As seen in left Temporal Lobe Epilepsy, will lead to the patient being overanalytical and referring to thoughts of personal destiny and philosophy and having a humorless approach to life.

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed?
questions.solution:
Abreaction is a psychoanalytical term for reliving an experience to release it emotionally. It is a specific type of catharsis done by becoming conscious of repressed traumatic events.

Catharsis is a general term for the process of releasing strong or repressed emotions. It can be done through various mediums, like expressing emotions through art. When the unconscious repressed memories are consciously recalled and relived, this technique specifically is called abreaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of personality disorders?

choices.text: They are not due to organic disease

questions.solution:
Personality disorders have an onset in adolescence or early adulthood.

It continues into late adulthood and matures.

Features of personality disorder:

  • Fixed and inflexible belief
  • Long-standing
  • Maladaptive and pervasive
  • Ego-syntonic (does not cause distress to the individual)
  • Not caused due to disease or substance abuse

questions.text: A student applied to four national universities for her MBA course but was disheartened when she got rejected from all four universities. While talking to her friend on the phone, she said she never wanted to go anyway because they were too far from home. What defense mechanism is being used by her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards rationalization. The student is rationalizing her rejection by saying she wouldn't have gone even if she got accepted because of the distance from home.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the mental status examination?

choices.text: It has objective observations of the clinician
It has subjective description given by the patient
It should be interpreted in the context of patient's cultural background

questions.solution:
Mental Status Examination (MSE) is a structured way of observing and describing a patient's psychological functioning at a given point in time. It does not involve the scoring of a patient.

The main components of MSE are:

  1. Appearance and behavior
  2. Mood and affect
  3. Speech
  4. Thought process and content
  5. Perceptual disturbances
  6. Sensorium and cognition
  7. Insight
  8. Judgment

When conducting the MSE or interpreting MSE findings, it is important to consider the cultural background of both the clinician conducting the MSE and the interviewee because behavioral patterns vary significantly across cultures (e.g., nodding your head as a sign of approval in some countries might signify disagreement in others)

Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), also known as Folstein's test, is done out of a score out of 30 and is used to measure cognitive impairment.

Note: Mental Status Examination (MSE) and Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) are two different assessment tests.

questions.text: A 21 year old male who is been treated for schizophrenia is put on haloperidol. A week after the initiation of medication the patient shows restlessness, irritability and cannot sit at one place. The most appropriate treatment strategy is
questions.solution:
• The symptoms of restlessness, irritability and inability to sit at one place a week after initiation of antipsychotic is ‘Akathisia’ which is the extrapyramidal side effect of the antipsychotics.
  • The most appropriate treatment of this condition is addition of beta blocker (Propranolol)

questions.text: The police charged two college students with drunken driving and brought them to the hospital for confirmation of their alcohol levels. On examination, the driver did not appear drunk and denied the charges, while the other student was clearly drunk and was barely conscious. However, the blood reports came back suggesting both of them having similarly elevated levels of alcohol. Which of the following is a possible explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
The given situation can be best explained by the Mellanby effect.

The Mellanby effect is the phenomenon where an individual’s perceived level of impairment at identical blood alcohol concentration (BAC) levels is greater when the BAC is rising (while drinking) than when it is falling (after drinking).

The clip below describes the Mellanby effect seen originally in a dog experiment.

Option B: Intermediate syndrome is a delayed-onset of muscular weakness and paralysis following an episode of organophosphate (acute cholinesterase inhibitor) poisoning.

Option C: Reverse tolerance refers to the phenomenon when an individual requires a lesser dose of alcohol (drug) to obtain the same effect as before.

Option D: Grand Rapids effect or dip is a controversial effect noted in certain studies where a BAC of 0.01–0.04% slightly lowered the risk of being in a vehicle accident when compared to a BAC of 0.00%

questions.text: You are interviewing a patient online. On asking the patient how she has been, she replies "I'm doing gooder, gerkschier". Her attender also informs that she uses such made-up words often. What disorder of thought is she exhibiting?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is exhibiting neologism. Neologism is a disorder of the form of thought. This refers to making new words (gooder, gerkschier) that do not exist and using them meaninglessly. It is usually seen in schizophrenia.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

    • Medication
    • Another medical condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Korsakoff syndrome?
questions.solution:
Long-term memory is normal in Korsakoff syndrome. In Korsakoff syndrome, immediate recall is impaired but long-term memory is preserved. 

Korsakoff syndrome is a type of diencephalic amnesia, caused by chronic thiamine deficiency and alcohol abuse.

Clinically, subjects with Korsakoff syndrome present with the following:

  • Severe anterograde amnesia - striking inability to form new memories 
  • Impaired mental syndrome (especially recent memory)
  • Present with confabulation, as an attempt to cover the memory deficit
  • Retrograde amnesia is less severe, but present.
  • Implicit learning (e.g., learning procedures) are preserved
  • Overall intact intelligence

questions.text: During Ross's marriage to Emily, when the wedding officiant asked him to repeat “I Ross, take thee, Emily, as my lawfully wedded wife”, Ross says Rachel's name instead. Ross and Rachel have dated on multiple occasions in the past. This unconscious act of revealing his feelings can be best described by which of the following terms?
questions.solution:
When a person reveals his feelings unconsciously by a slip of tongue, it is known as parapraxis. Freud ascribed parapraxis to unconscious motives.

Option B: Transference - A situation where the feelings, desires, and expectations of one person are redirected and applied to another person. Most commonly, transference occurs in a therapeutic setting, where a person in therapy unconsciously develop feelings towards the therapist.

Option C: Repression - is a key concept of psychoanalysis, where it is understood as a defense mechanism. It ensures that what is unacceptable to the conscious mind - and would, if recalled arouse anxiety - is prevented from entering into it.

Option D: Displacement - Feelings that are connected with one person are displaced onto another person. E.g., a man who has had a bad day at the office, comes home and yells at his wife and children, is displacing his anger from the workplace onto his family.

Catharsis: The expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed emotions by the patient which provides a sense of relief. It is also known as ventilation. In catharsis, the patient reveals information voluntarily and consciously whereas, in parapraxis, patient details are revealed unconsciously, by slip of tongue.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic who hadn’t consumed alcohol for the past 3 days was brought to the emergency department. He had features of disorientation, poor attention span, and agitation. On examination, he had fever, tachycardia, and diaphoresis. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of disorientation with features of autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever) in a patient who stopped alcohol 3 days back is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal.

Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide and lorazepam are used in the treatment and prevention of delirium tremens.

Option A: Korsakoffs psychosis is characterized by impaired mental abilities (especially recent memory) and anterograde amnesia in an alert and responsive patient. The patient may have symptoms of confabulation.

Option B: Wernicke's encephalopathy is characterized by ataxia (affecting primarily the gait), vestibular dysfunction, confusion, and ocular motility abnormalities.

Option D: Alcohol-induced dementia is characterized by the development of multiple cognitive deficits (e.g., memory problems, language impairment, and an inability to perform complex motor tasks) that are judged to be a direct consequence of alcohol use. This persists beyond the usual duration of alcohol intoxication or acute withdrawal.

A recent study found that even moderate alcohol consumption reduces grey matter, up to 0.8% of the volume reduction, more than any other modifiable risk factor including smoking.

questions.solution:
Clonidine will not be effective in this patient.

questions.text: Catalepsy occurs in _____
questions.solution:
Catalepsy:

  • Passively allowing the examiner to position the body or a body part (waxy flexibility).
  • A feature of catatonia.

Cataplexy:

  • Sudden and transient episode of loss of muscle tone.
  • Full conscious awareness.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. His moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for him?
questions.solution:
The patient has rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid-cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year

Episodes either have a partial or full remission for at least 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine has been found to have limited uses in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. It can prolong the time between depression and mania.

Option C: Carbamazepine takes 2-3 weeks for the onset of action and is used in patients not responding to Lithium in Acute Mania.

Option D: Lithium takes 5-7 days to achieve a level of equilibrium, moreover it is effective in Bipolar I disorder and is less efficacious than Divalproex in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder.

 

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add-on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with symptoms of low mood, fatigue, and failure to experience pleasure in any activities. He also complains of insomnia and lack of concentration. These symptoms are present during most of the months of winter and completely remit during spring. The symptoms have been recurring over the past 3 years. What is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Major Depressive Disorder with seasonal pattern

questions.solution:
Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario. 

Features of major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern: 

  • Onset and remission of major depressive episodes at specific times of the year.
  • In most cases, the episodes begin in the fall or winter and remit in spring.
  • This pattern of onset and remission of episodes must have occurred during at least a 2-year period, without any
    nonseasonal episodes during this period.
  • In addition, the seasonal depressive episodes must substantially outnumber any nonseasonal depressive episodes over the individual's lifetime.
  • Absence of seasonally linked psychosocial stressors (e.g., seasonal unemployment or school schedule).
  • Major depressive episodes that occur in a seasonal pattern are often characterized by prominent energy, hypersomnia, overeating, weight gain, and a craving for carbohydrates.

Note: According to ICD-11, seasonal depressive disorder is included under recurrent depressive disorders.

questions.text: The following are phases of grief following the loss of a loved one except:
questions.solution:
Bargaining is not a phase of grief following the loss of a loved one.

The phases of grief following the loss of a loved one include: 

1. Shock and denial (minutes, days, weeks):

  • Disbelief and numbness
  • Searching behaviors: pining, yearning, and protest

2. Acute anguish (weeks, months):

  • Waves of somatic distress
  • Withdrawal
  • Preoccupation
  • Anger
  • Guilt

3.Lost patterns of conduct:

  • Restless and agitated
  • Aimlessness and loss of motivation
  • Identification with the bereaved

4.Resolution (months, years):

  • Have grieved
  • Return to work
  • Resume old roles
  • Acquire new roles
  • Reexperience pleasure
  • Seek companionship and love of other

Note: Bargaining is one of the five phases of death and dying proposed by Kubler-Ross. It is also known as stages of grief in the terminally ill. The Kubler-Ross model postulates a progression of emotional states experienced by the terminally ill patients confronting their own death. 

The 5 stages of death and dying include:

  • Shock and Denial
  • Anger
  • Bargaining
  • Depression
  • Acceptance

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc).

questions.solution:

Motor and vocal tics are divided into simple and complex types.

 More purposeful and ritualistic than simple tics.

Examples:

questions.text: When pharmacotherapy is necessary for managing delirium, which of the following is preferred as the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Haloperidol is commonly used for the first-line pharmacological treatment of delirium.

The two major symptoms of delirium that may require pharmacological treatment are psychosis and insomnia.

Options A, B: Benzodiazepines are often used as an adjunct in agitated patients, but should be used judiciously for insomnia as their sedative property can worsen confusion in delirium. 

Option C: The use of second-generation antipsychotics may be considered for delirium management, but clinical trial experience with these agents for delirium is limited. Clozapine itself is known to sometimes trigger delirium.

Note: IV regimens of haloperidol are mostly used in the ICU in the critically ill due to their fast onset of action and predictable pharmacokinetics. Oral haloperidol may be used as a maintenance regimen in patients with a functional GI tract. Intramuscular haloperidol is considered only in acutely combative patients without IV access.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents for behavioral issues at home and school. Which of the following features in this child satisfies the core diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder?
  1. He is fixated on a shiny red wrapper in the trash bin in the room.
  2. The mother reports that he does not appear to respond to affection.
  3. The child constantly lines up his toys.
  4. Reports from his school describe poor language development.
  5. He is noted to have a mild intellectual disability.
questions.solution:
Aberrant language development and intellectual disability are not part of the core diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder, according to the DSM-5 update.

Core diagnostic impairments in autism spectrum disorders according to DSM-5 are collapsed into two domains:

1. Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts:

  • Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity
  • Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors (e.g. eye contact, body language, use of gestures, and facial expressions)
  • Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships (e.g. difficulties in sharing, imaginative play, or in making friends)

2. Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by at least two of the following:

  • Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech (e.g. simple motor stereotypies, lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia)
  • Inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns and behavior (e.g. extreme distress at small changes, difficulties with transitions, rigid thinking patterns)
  • Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus (e.g, strong preoccupation with unusual objects)
  • Hyper- or hypo-reactivity to sensory input (e.g., apparent indifference to pain/temperature, adverse response to specific sounds or textures, excessive smelling or touching of objects, visual fascination with lights or movement).

questions.text: A police inspector is investigating a murder case. The victim was brutally beaten and raped. The body had noose marks on the neck which seemed to be the cause of death. However, during the investigation, the inspector never showed any emotion. What defense mechanism is described here?
questions.solution:
The defense mechanism described is isolation. It is the separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

It is usually developed in an attempt to avoid painful thoughts or feelings by emotionally detaching oneself from the feeling.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: What does Ribot’s law deal with?
questions.solution:
Ribot's law deals with retrograde amnesia.

During incidents of retrograde amnesia, most recently acquired memories are the most vulnerable to disruption from brain damage. This temporal gradation of retrograde amnesia that preferentially spares the more distant memories is known as Ribot's law.

E.g: If an incident causing retrograde amnesia occurs at 30 years of age, the memories acquired at 25 years of age may be more severely affected than those memories acquired at 20 years of age or earlier.

questions.text: A scared 18-year-old boy presented with a belief that his penis is retracting into his abdomen and that he would die when it completely retracts. What is this disorder known as?
questions.solution:
Koro is a culture-bound syndrome seen in Asia (including India). The affected male person has the belief that his penis is shrinking and may disappear into his abdominal wall and he may then die. It is usually based on the culturally elaborated fears regarding nocturnal emission and masturbation (particularly in men).

Females are also affected infrequently, with a corresponding belief that their breasts (and/or vulva) are shrinking.

Other culture-bound syndromes:

Dhat syndrome is seen in the Indian subcontinent. It is characterized by the complaint of the passage of dhat (whitish discharge: semen) in urine, multiple somatic symptoms, physical/mental exhaustion, sexual dysfunction. It is based on the belief that semen is precious and loss of semen leads to exhaustion and weakness.

Latah (startle reaction) is a syndrome seen in South-East Asia and Japan. Occurring more often in women, latah is typically characterized by the presence of automatic obedience, echolalia (mimicking another's speech), and echopraxia (mimicking another's movement). It is often precipitated by a sudden stimulus, such as a loud sound.

Shenkui is native to China, and also exists globally, in which the individual suffers withdrawal-like symptoms including painful brain fog, chills, nausea, and even flu-like symptoms with anxiety, believed to be caused by a loss of semen and orgasm. The symptoms can last weeks to months after a single orgasm.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with schizoaffective disorder and was prescribed a drug. Soon after initiation of therapy, she developed galactorrhea and dysmenorrhea, and her prolactin level was 171.6ng/mL. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Risperidone causes the maximum rise in prolactin levels and has the highest potential to cause hyperprolactinemia among the atypical antipsychotics.

Risperidone is an antagonist of 5-HT2A and D2 receptors. The combined use of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) can also result in a significant elevation of prolactin with galactorrhea and breast enlargement.

questions.text:
A patient who is a known case of bipolar disorder with psychotic features is currently on the following medications. However, he continues to have pressured speech, flight of ideas, hallucinations, and suicidal ideations. He is planned for electroconvulsive therapy. Which of the following drugs would you stop before the procedure?
  1. Diazepam
  2. Lithium
  3. Risperidone
  4. Bupropion
  5. Moclobemide
questions.solution:
Lithium, diazepam, and bupropion should be withheld before a session of ECT.

Lithium combined with ECT has been shown to cause prolonged seizures (lasting more than 180 secs) and increased postictal delirium. Doses are withheld for 24 hours prior to treatment, allowing for washout.

Medications to be withheld before ECT:

  1. Lithium - causes prolonged seizures and increased postictal delirium
  2. Benzodiazepines - anticonvulsant activity
  3. Clozapine - associated with late-appearing seizures
  4. Buproprion - associated with late-appearing seizures

Medications that should not be used during ECT:

  1. Lidocaine - markedly increases seizure threshold
  2. Theophylline - increases the duration of seizures
  3. Reserpine - further compromises RS and CVS

Note: Tardive seizure is a rare complication of ECT. These are seizures that occur after the completion of treatment once the patient has regained consciousness. The use of β-lactam antibiotics and ciprofloxacin has been associated with tardive seizures.

questions.text: A young man presented with a 2-week history of auditory hallucinations and delusions of grandiosity. His history is significant for severe depression with psychotic symptoms. However, he has been euthymic for the past month. According to DSM-5, what would be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points toward the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder. 

DSM-5 criteria for schizoaffective disorder:  

  • An uninterrupted period of illness where there is a mood episode (depression or mania) concurrent with psychosis (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc.)
  • Delusions or hallucinations (psychotic symptoms) for at least two weeks in the absence of a major depressive or manic episode during the lifetime course of the illness.
  • Mood symptoms present for the majority of total illnesses.
  • Not due to intake of substances or another medical condition.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features: Psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during mood episodes.
  • Schizophrenia: Mood symptoms are absent or present for only brief periods during the course of the illness dominated by psychotic symptoms.

Note: According to DSM-5 guidelines, for a definitive diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, there have to be two psychotic episodes. One of the psychotic episodes has to be concurrent with a severe affective (depression or manic) episode. The other psychotic episode should be for two or more weeks in the absence of affective symptoms. And affective symptoms should dominate the major part during the lifetime course of the illness.
